Comment: So will everyone else in that movement. The thing with reactionary movements is that they self-select on selfishness and exceptionalism. The core reactionary idea is that society is a fixed moral and social hierarchy based on identity (i.e. we can do no wrong because of who we are, and deserve privileges for that same reason). But people need to be susceptible to some form of selfishness and exceptionalism in order to subscribe to it. They need to want to look down on others, to feel they deserve to be and have more, they need to feel special and chosen.   This is decidedly a double edged sword because that exceptionalism renders them blind to the inevitability of being "othered" themselves. And due to the selfishness, they'll never stand up for anyone else even before that happens, so there is never any solidarity to push back against internal purges.  They'll gleefully participate in the ostracism or persecution of others, and are then totally surprised when it happens to them too. And it has to happen, of course, because the ideology is hollow and wrong. There is nothing constructive there, no solutions for any problem, so instead there is a never ending need for scapegoats and distractions.  Unfortunately for everyone else, given access to power these movements tend to take society with them when they destroy themselves.

Comment: Fwiw, in February 78% of American Catholics viewed the pope favourably, including 23% who viewed him very favourably.  These numbers are a big decline from his halcyon days in 2015, when 90% were favourable and 57% were very favourable, and from the days of JPII, who was regularly over 90%.   But it's still a.lot of popularity compared to any political figure and most celebrities. And Francis was generally more popular than Benedict (usually low 70s or even high 60s).  Likewise, although a small number of bishops were hostile to him, particularly early on, the american conference of bishops was generally supportive.

Comment: The most detailed accounts of Alexander were written hundreds of years after his death, the Gospels were written some 50-ish years after Jesus. Author: KnezNikola

Comment: John was probably written around 110, so not just decades. And the idea that it's the most historically accurate ancient text is very much one propped up by creationist type groups and ignores just how much of the Bible is undermined by geological evidence. And yeah, a lot of ancient history is unreliable - it's the case with Alexander, with our history of the Vikings that was massively influenced by the christianity of the people writing it even though those Vikings described were not in any way christian, etc etc etc. Other histories being unreliable in certain aspects doesn't make yours more accurate.
Author: TaCZennith

Comment: Geological evidence does put something like Genesis under scrutiny but in no way does it discredit The Gospels. The Bible is a collection of Books, differing in the genre they were written. You cant put Genesis and Psalms under the same lense when one is not intended on being taken literally (especially early chapters of Genesis) and when the other is quite literally poetry written by various authors. The Gospels are Greco-Roman biographies, one of the more extensive collections for the time. Usually, only high class people had this much written about them, not a Jewish Carpenter from Judea
